content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												A serious sniping game. Lurking in the bush, finding a good position and placing one single, perfect shot, only to sneak away unseen and leaving not a trace. Like the shadow of a ghost in the jungle. Sniper: Ghost Warrior is just about as far from this ideal as it is possible to come.As a sniper, your primary tool lies simply in not being seen. This would typically entail you wanting to stay off roads, footpaths and other places where people usually travel. In S:GW, you can only dream of this. The area in which you can move is so narrow, you'd get claustrophobia if it weren't for the fact that it looks relatively pretty. The catch is, there are so many invisible walls, idiotically placed fences (which you cannot jump over, of course), stupid fishing nets across the creek (which you cannot cut, even though you're carrying a knife), columns that just happened to have fallen just so, etc. etc.The whole game is pretty much based on railroading of the highest order: You have to go there, to that exact rock shelf, before the victim decides to stroll out of his cabin. At one point, you are actually told to place a claymore on the path "in case there's a chase". (Three guesses what happens just after you take the shot ...)Sight adjustments though. At least they have that down, right? As if ... you're left relying on Kentucky Windage. Because the game is actually simulating wind. You even have a wind gauge that is visible in the scope, to help you place your shots properly. That would be handy, if it hadn't been for the fact that the wind is completely random. But they've solved that problem for you as well: You see, you have a tiny red circle travelling around the crosshairs, which tells you precisely where your bullet will hit. All so you don't have to worry about boring things like finding the range or elevation relative to your target. Because who would want that in a sniper game. Oh, and is that magic circle moving too fast for you? Don't worry, you can just press shift to go into bullet-time. /facepalmBut they do have bullet-drop, so they have at least modelled ballistics to some degree. Yay.So, you know where you'll hit before you fire your shots. Or so you would think. Well, you'll just have to hope that the chain-link fence through which you're shooting, is of the type that bullet's can actually penetrate. Because not everything is as it seems in this game. You can shoot through (some) walls, but not through all chain-link fences. You can jump up on a ledge only to meet an invisible wall 10 cm further in, etc. etc.With so many things about which to be annoyed, it seems almost banal to point out that the level design is hopelessly bad (e.g. the obvious railroading) and that the scenarios are completely unrealistic. For example: you're asked to sneak into the middle of a military installation carrying a weapon whose optimum range is >300m. Luckily, the AI is so moronic, it doesn't really matter: You can be lying on the other side of a river, taking out infantry in a village chock full of them, and they won't bat an eyelid when their friend mysteriously decides to start the siesta 8 hours prematurely. 2 meters away from them. The loud bang immediately following is obviously completely unrelated. But don't try to walk up-right behind an enemy instead of crouching like you've learned, because then they've suddenly got superman-hearing and flash-reflexes and you're dead before you even have time to jump.At some point in time, I think the developers realized that they weren't really working on the worlds greatest sniper game, because in the middle of the game you suddenly change roles and run around like a regular infantryman with an M16 or similar rifle. And if the game is lousy as a sniper game, it really sucks as a standard "run & gun". Everything is still just as fricking scripted: The enemies come running only once you walk through the gate (which is of course your only choice of route) and your allies faithfully wait for you to be a pointman and advance the battle. Meanwhile, they're busy, locked in an eternal gunfight with the AI, none of whom seem to be able to hit the broad side of a barn. So it is in fact an illusion that you have helpers in the grunt scenarios. In reality, you're just as alone there as you are in the forest. The only difference is you're playing an abysmal infantry game instead of a boring sniper game.Small blessings and everything, but I'm so glad I followed my gut feeling and didn't fork out for this game at full price, but waited for the infamous holiday sale. But even at todays low, low price, this game isn't worth it.

												The first Sniper experience is a very bad one. Make no mistake: the game looks decent and there's a lot of emphasis on the sniping action which feels a lot of fun. The features section of the game's store page highlights the importance of weather, wind and how the bullet trajectory / drop can be affected by them. It's all good but just not enough to result in a good game.Campaign is short and extremely difficult. While sniping is fun you are told exactly where to go and what to do. It is so heavily scripted that under no circumstances do you feel you should try it again. From time to time you are in the shoes of a soldier only allowed to handle rifles or SMGs. Fighting with these is very difficult. It has nothing to do with how these weapons work: the enemy can just easily spot you and shoot you down. This switching back and forth from the easy sniping and the very hard gunning sequences just makes the game unplayable.In addition to this, I was unable to find any games online. Not that after the horrible single player I wanted any. Sniper Ghost Warrior is an original game: its creators knew a lot of people liked sniping so they developed a game with that in mind. It was just not executed properly. If they had taken the time to refine the campaign and completely get rid of the non-sniper weapons this would have easily been on top of the list of my favourite games.

ProsThe game features fairly decent sniping mechanics. It takes into account distance, bullet drop, momentum and wind which makes shooting a bit more engaging that just pointing the reticle at the enemy and firing. If all of this sound daunting to you, don't fret. The game does feature “aim assist” in the form of a dot that lets you know where to fire from.The story is not THAT bad (its not good though)ConsThe game is riddled with bugs and clipping issuesThe game suffers from some hit detection issue. Sometimes shooting straight at a guy will not register and if an enemy is being any type for foliage he will not get hit at all.The A.I is pretty stupid and seems to be activate when you look at them which is weird.The sound design is just bad. The voice acting is not that great, the enemies have the exact same dialogue from the beginning of the game to the end and the sound effects are pretty poor.. At several point in the game I have heard Soldier A and Soldier B having a conversation where both were saying the exact same lines.The game is very short. I finished the main campaign on Normal in three and half hour and the dlc campaign in about one hour. There is another challenge mode that I did not touch.Looking at the Pros and Cons it seems as though the game is not worth playing but I have found myself enjoying every moment of the game. It is campy, it is buggy and never rises above mediocre but it was just fun; Sneaking around sniping people, seeing your plan of attack succeed or even just hitting a guy while he is running were all very fulfilling. I recommend the game to people that can overlook some of its flaws and focus on the good that is in there (however little that is).

Posted: September 27, 2014
												Sniper: Ghost Warrior is a generic, no-name game with a few bugs.The entire concept of this game is that the one element that is only a portion of other games – the sniper mode – is the entire focus. The problem with focusing on one element of a game is that you need to do that element extremely well in order to be successful. While this game does do this well – the camera angles and feeling you get while sniping is very good.Sniper: Ghost Warrior puts you in the midst of a deadly conflict in South America. It’s your duty as an American soldier to assist the rebels in overthrowing the dictator of this fictional country. Combat locations are varied, from urban streets to the sweltering humid jungles. There’s no shortage of action, and like the locations, the gameplay is varied.There’s nothing terrible about this game, and there's also nothing terribly original either. There are some technical issues which keep it from ever being considered a classic. Some of the glitches you'll encounter include clipping graphics and control command errors. In some instances you can see through walls and other structures. Unfortunately it also appears the A.I. has this ability as they can pinpoint your location with uncanny accuracy once you’ve fired off a shot.A sniper’s life isn’t all sunshine and lollipops, so expect the unexpected, along with some frustrating elements you will have little control over.Despite the clipping, the graphics are well done, creating spacious environments such as the villages and jungle areas. There isn’t much story to concern you, just follow orders and keep yourself alive.Like Splinter Cell, there is a meter to determine your level of stealth in relation to the enemy's perception. It will indicate the degree the enemy is aware of your presence, so you’ll always have instant feedback on your progress making the stealth segments more exciting. Ghost Warrior is a bit like a basically excellent rough diamond, that no one wanted to polish any further. It's got good ideas and good visuals, but nowadays, that alone just isn't enough to be able to keep up with the competition.Overall 6/10.

												I have no idea whats going on in this game whatsoever.The story is rather odd to be honest.You're stuck somewhere in south America, trying to disrupt some general from doing some bad things. But before that you're rushed through a training mission that emphasizes how important stealth is in the game, then it immediately forgets all pretenses of stealth as it confusedly tries to rush you through an action campaign, which it feels like there was a rift going on here. Half the studio probably wanted to make the next Call of Duty game, and then the other half wanted to make something more like the Sniper Elite series.So you run through an earlier part of the mission with your buddy who has a weird callsign that you'll forget three seconds after hearing it, then you go through some combat and he gets taken back for his six o clock dental appointment on a boat, which you're glad he's gone because he's a terrible teammate anyways. Then you're supposed to escape using stealth, meanwhile you can't actually be stealthy. Like one area of the map where you're supposed to get from one end of the village to the other while being super sneaky, you climb through the tall grass, taking everything super slow, waiting for enemies to move, learning their pathing, generally being super good with your tactics. And then out of nowhere, ♥♥♥♥boy davey decides to shoot you with his gun because he somehow saw this elite trained sniper in his native environment... Yeah, GG on that one.But then because the game gets bored, they quickly drop you on an oil rig where you're supposed to be doing some fast paced actiony shooty shooty sections, all the while I'm sitting here thinking "I bought Sniper game, but right now I'm not even carrying a sniper rifle at all!" That section ends and then you get back to the mainland, 'whew, time to do more sniping!' but nah, one member of your squad (oh yeah, you pick up a few guys at one point and then they go break on tea time, really I don't know where they went, I just looked up at one moment and they left me) gets hit by a sniper bullet, and then you have to go through this terribly designed village in order to uh..... do a thing I guess? I have no idea what the main goal for this game is yet, and I feel/hope I'm most of the way through the game (Honestly I was just playing and sorta raged at a certain section of the game, I'll get to that later) But this village has very few paths, actually really just one path, there were only maybe multiple paths because I found a way to get around some invisible walls. And by this point the AI have somehow downloaded an aimbot.exe because they're outsniping the trained sniper. Also this particular section was frustrating because the amount of cover was minimal, the enemies were spread out far, (meaning that if you move your character half an inch to the side, like five of them now have an angle to shoot you from) and even with the lack of cover, there's no good way to work around it. A decent peeking system would have made this part much smoother without providing an unfair advantage to players. Not to mention moving around the tight corridors in the building nearby is nearly impossible when your character feels like a piece of clay with two wheels and a gun attached to him. After you've finished that area you go and try and kill some more guys that you quickly realize are nearly indistinguishable from the vegetation nearby (though somehow they instantly see you when you're climbing around in the brush, actively TRYING to be sneaky) and then for no reason whatsoever, the game teleports you to a lighthouse for you to shoot people from. (I should mention that I wanted to test out how amazingly easy it was for the AI to spot me, so I went prone at the top of this tower, just observing them, and then boom... one guy popped out of a truck and shot me just about immediately after his boots touched the ground....) At this point I don't know whether I'm playing as five different characters or not. Like how the hell did I randomly get to a lighthouse? Did I spirit hop into one of the other guys in the squad, and he's decided to get onto a lighthouse? Can't be because my player has the same voice! So what happened then? Am I secretly a member of the X-men that just teleports wherever he wants? Oh well, at least in this particular spot I have a sniper rifle... for the second time in the game.

												The concept is appealling, the execution rather mediocre.The field of view is excessively narrow, and this hurts the quality of the gameplay during the non-sniping parts (which are several), the three difficulties do not differ from the AI quality as much as they differ from how inaccurate and clueless the enemy can be at the lowest difficutly, and how absurdly aware and accurate they are on the hardest.For a game from 2010 I would expect a better graphic department, especially being City Interactive an established game developer with several 3D titles on its record; however, even maxing out the settings the game looks poorly executed, with textures that, at times, seem to come straight out of 1999. The contrast between the good level design, the beautiful scenarios the Chrome Engine 4 creates and the poor texture quality generates a terrible outcome, that not even a breathtaking story and a great sound department can compensate.After having played for an hour it will appear clear how this game was developed with console players in mind, and eventually ported to PC; the result, as you may imagine, is quite atrocious for a first person shooter.In the end the gameplay experience is original, but the terrible execution doesn't make this a product worth your time.If you need ratings:Graphic: 6/10Sound: 8/10Gameplay: 4/10Longevity: 5/10Overall: 5/10

The most realistic sniping experience in a video game ever, right down to managing your breathing for increased accuracy of sniper shots.First of all, there is nothing realistic in this game what so ever. If by "managing your breathing" you mean press one button to instantly stabilise your aim, then yes. Enjoy a fully realistic ballistic system that accounts for bullet trajectory, including bullet drop and environmental effects such as wind, fog & rain.This is not true. The ballistic system does not follow wind at all. It is literally just random no matter what weather. Pull off the perfect headshot and watch your bullet strike the enemy with pin-point accuracy in Bullet Cam mode. 4 types of sniping rifles: AS50, MSG90, SR25 & SVD DragunovWait, why would I want to destroy the immersion by taking me straight out of the game in a bullet cam? But why would I use 3 other sniper rifles when the automatic one comes with 300 bullets and you kill everyone in one hit anyway? A variety of mission types ranging from sniper vs. sniper elimination, real-time tactical assault and fixed machine gun combat.No, there is not a single mission where you fight other snipers. Maybe they are refering to the shotgunners that can hit you on 750 meter distances. There is one mission where you shoot one sniper, but never "Snipers".Yes, you did not read that wrong. They just used fixed machine gun combat as a selling point. Play as two separate characters: the sniper and the spotter.There is one mission where you have to look in your binoculars and click on a few soldiers in the correct order. Otherwise you fail instantly. And your sniper buddy can shoot through solid mountain and houses.

Which brings me to the bad stuff about this game.So you are a sniper so stealth is a big part of this game, and you are also camflauged. So what is the problem then?It's actually not so funny when you have a silenced sniper rifle, you shoot one enemy, and the rest of the enemies can, with pinpoint accuracy, shoot at you, even from a long distance. Though unlike the first game when you died almost instantly, you still lose health if you don't move. They somehow get alerted sometimes. AND then you will have an unsilenced sniper gun; you fire that and no one seems to be bothered by it. This is actually quite frustrating when there is one level you have to get through by stealth alone. You shoot one guy silenced, and everyone in the area is on alert. So if your foot is exposed, forget it, you are dead.The next thing which I consider pretty bad are the weapons. Not the weapons themselves mind you. I can say it was interesting to play where distance and wind are a factor to how your bullet will travel. There is on easier levels, a red dot on your scope to help you. You see. I am a Counter-Strike player and the only weapons that you use for zooming are scoped weapons. In this game, the cross hairs are so open that you are forced to use iron sights to shoot, and by doing so, you cannot see your target properly due to the visual of your gun being in the way. The takes out the presicion of aiming when you are trying to strafe and hell, even to try locking a position down.I was enjoying this game, but because of the issues I see here, I found myself rushing to finish the game fast, just to get it over and done with. The maps are good and unique, which is why I continued to play the game to completion. I won't discredit that.This game does have potential, but due to my observations on it, I am not even inclined to want to play multiplayer. Becasue I bought this in a bundle, I hope Sniper 2 proves to be much better than this game. We can only hope.If you try to compare it to the Sniper Elite games, they are similar, but not the same kind of games. I would suggest watching YouTube videos for this game, just to you know what you are in for.

Posted: September 26, 2015
												   When I picked this one up, I was expecting a decent sniping game with some stealth and the occasional firefight mixed in. Those expectations were shot down, butchered, and had gasoline poured on them to make a lovely bonfire just to make sure nothing could be salvaged.    The game was quite enjoyable up until the oil rig, where you take over one of the members of the commando team in the first assault mission. The sniping mechanics might be good, but the assault rifle has so much kick you couldn't hit the broad side of a mountain half the time, much less a moving target shooting at you. I spent over an hour on the second assault mission just trying to clear the first part, pretty much having to save after every kill.   On the subject of accuracy, the enemy AIs have too much. you're sniping them from halfway across the map, and not only do they see you, they manage to accurately hit you half the time. With assault rifles and pistols. I know the game is supposed to have 'accurate ballistics', but I kind of expected it to be for BOTH SIDES, not just the player. To make matters worse, when you do have team mates, they tend to be very useless, when they actually move and not just stand around like statues. I was playing on meduim, and it felt more like extreme difficulty from other games.   Sufficed to say, this was a very badly done game. With the exception of the sniper rifle, pretty much every gun in the game sucks, and unless you play it on easy, expect some frustration. Even on easy, expect some frustration. Sufficed to say, I didn't get very far into the game, and I probably won't get much farther. This one quickly turned into a chore rather then a pleasure. If you feel the need to try Sniper: Ghost Warrior, get it when its on sale, cause it is not worth the full price.

Posted: March 16, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game, but no matter how hard I tried, in the end? I just couldn't.The game is a ton of fun and has variety to spice things up. Through most of the campaign you play as "Tyler" The sniper. You stealth through villages, slaughter hundreds of people via pistol or sniper rifle, and just be a general badass. However what I didn't see coming was that there are also several segments of the game where it turns into Call of Duty and you're taking oil rigs with an assault rifle as "Conway" a member of "Delta". It was an..interesting surprise but the mechanics in the game REALLY don't suit assault rifle gameplay.It runs decently on modern systems. Some graphical glitches unfortunately, ESPECIALLY if you're running multi-gpu. NOTE: Do not run this game with multi-GPU.The stealth system is basic. The graphics are...decent. Textures are horrible but character models and object models have their high-points. The sniping "circle" that indicates where your shot will land breaks occasionally, ESPECIALLY when you zoom further in with your scope. The main campaign is very short, about 5 hours. The DLC Campaign "Unfinished Business" will add about 3 hours to the game give or take (But is immensely frustruating due to an extremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ checkpoint system).The story is very uninteresting. I've finished both campaigns and I just remember bits and pieces of everything. I couldn't tell you who Tyler was employed with, why we were fighting who we were fighting or anything. I LOVE stories too, I buy games mostly for the stories! But this one is just pathetic.The characters are meh as well. Tyler is a regular individual, Conway is....a guy with a name...and O'Neil just has a voice actor that makes me want to remember him, but he was so underdeveloped I'll forget him in two days tops.The multiplayer is horrendous. Extreme server latency issues. Consistent fluctuating ping regardless of your internet connection. And all for what? A Call of Duty with nothing but snipers and silenced pistols? No thank you. (As well as broken server finding that stops you from hosting any server using any DLC weapons/maps due to the developer forgetting to include that information in the server list)All in all this game is not worth your time. There are MUCH better games out there, but if you have this one, no harm in giving it a try. It is drudgerous however, and your effort never pays off as the ending is likely the WORST part of this game. All 3 of them. (Yes, there are 3. The main campaign ending, the DLC ending, and then finding out you're not done and there's a "Challenge" mode that's 1 mission to end the entire game- which I never played because after 8 hours I grew SO sick of the game.)FInal Verdict is a 4/10. Sub-par, but not completely worthless.

Posted: October 2, 2016
												Slowly belly-crawling through the underbrush, I scan the distance for signs of enemy troops. I come to a sudden stop; inexplicably, an invisible wall blocks my forward progress. I crawl to the edge of the brush, frantically run across an exposed trail, and into the foliage to the left of the path, figuring that a different route might be in order, but I'm stymied again as I find myself stuck on a rock that raises only six inches off the ground. Finally, I find a way past these obstacles in the brush and silently arrive at my GPS designated destination marker, but my objective won't clear. I give up. Defeated, I walk back up the hill, walk down the path, which triggers a voiceover, which enables the GPS marker, which spawns enemies on the path ahead of me that kill me. This is my experience with Sniper: Ghost Warrior in a nutshell. 6/10PresentationSniper is sandwiched between static menus and boring, grammatically challenged loading screens.7.5/10GraphicsThe vibrant, busy environments are striking with some great lighting, but awful character models and a shoddy framerate hurts the experience6.5/10SoundBoilerplate music and bad Latin American accents can't hide Nolan North slumming it in the jungle.5.5/10GameplayThe sniping mechanic is sound, but its undercut by terrible level design and unwieldy run and gun sequences.7/10Lasting AppealThe single player campaign will last about 12 hours, and multiplayer offers a decent variety of gametypes.

Posted: December 13, 2014
												It's fun, but not perfect. Many flaws, but mostly enjoyable. That's the TL;DR of all my thoughts on the game.I came into this expecting blandness, but I must say, the parts where you're sniping are VERY enjoyable. It feels very nice to control, and after getting a hang of it, it's really easy to headshot people. When it goes into the bullet cam, that feels great. If this game was entirely sniping, I'd give it a much higher rating.The problem is, you're not always sniping. There's parts where you must use an assault rifle, and it feels AWFUL. Horrible hit detection and hardly any damage, and the enemies basically have aimbots, while you can't even see them. It feels very tacked on, and the game suffers for it.There are quite a few glitches, from clipping issues, to my teammates falling off of a boat, to this random invincible aimbot guy that could kill me in less than a second from half a mile away. Most of these were quite hilarious, except for that aimbot guy.The story's not original in any sense, but I didn't expect much. It's a bit better than most of these macho military man game stories, though.But honestly, even with the glitches and the assault rifle parts, on the whole this is a quite enjoyable game. My playtime is how long it took me to beat single player on normal. I didn't bother trying multiplayer because I assume's that's dead.I will indeed recommend it. Play it if you want to have an enjoyable sniping experience, and are willing to overlook some flaws.Tip: If you manually save, it's like a savestate wherever you put it, and deaths will return you to it. So, you could savescum through the assault rifle parts, for instance.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												This game can't decide what it wants to be - stealth sniper or straight-out FPS. This results in absurd situations. For example, in stealth levels, enemies will raise the alarm the moment they see you, but won't as long as they don't - EVEN IF you just shot the guy standing right next to them. For another example, the in-game radar doesn't show enemies until you look at them - a great logical idea. However, enemies show on your radar if you cross sufficiently close to them, even if you never directly looked at them. At other times, the radar won't register a enemy if you are looking at him through your scope - extremely weird for a game titled Sniper.There are 3 stances - standing, crouching and crawling. Ideally, you should be forced to choose between running from cover to cover or slowly crawling in the hopes of being undetected. In the game though, you just have to crawl always.Worst of all  are the controls. Totally unresponsive and the mouse sensitivity is way too high.And I would expect a stealth game to have a separate key for lying prone. Nope - you have to long-press the crouch key.Even CoD has separate keys for these stances.

												Sniper: Ghost Warrior is one of my favorite sniper games so far. Graphics:I really loved the graphics. I was particularly impressed by the way your vision goes when your eyes are submerged into water, but you are not swimming. Such details are missed by many game companies. As far as the greenery goes, true, it is not the easiest to see when you are hiding in some, but in my opinion, this only enchances the experience. Just like in real life, you cannot see through leaves. Shuffle a bit and you will get that hit no problem.Story:Story is not as deep as I would like it to be, but it is decent regardless. You are told what to do, and you do it. In some cases even, you tell other snipers what to do by scouting the area and marking enemies for them. The ending lacked some action and story line after the final enemy has been assassinated.General:Aiming is good, it depends from the distance, the wind, your pulse and I'm not sure what else. This does not make it difficult, because if you have time to focus for a few seconds and calm your pulse down, you will be able to see exactly where will the bullet land. This way you are able to get very satisfying head shots, shown by a bullet cam. The game has a very nice balance in difficulty, as well as keeping you interested as you continue to play on. Mission types change, story goes on, and most of all, you have to be VERY careful. Enemies are marked on your map only once you see them, but until then, there is really no telling where they could be, unless if you can hear them (walking, speaking to each other, using a mobile phone).Bugs/complaints:Here I would like to leave my opinion on some of the problems people complained about, and gave this game a bad recommendation:1. Invisible walls everywhere!Honestly, I haven't found a single invisible barrier, if they were there in the past, they are gone.2. Enemies kill you so easily!True, but is this a bad thing though? After all, we are talking about a stealth sniper game, not counter strike. You wouldn't feel very well either if there were 5 bullets inside of you.3. They are such good marksman!I found the skill of enemies aiming to be proportional to the distance they are from you. If they are really far, they will have trouble even seeing you. If we are talking close range, yes, they are good, but then again, probably a person who never held a gun would make that shot as well and at the end of the day, so are you.4. Game is so linear!You have an objective. That objective has its location. If you want to explore, you are very much welcome to do so, it is even encouraged through 'Secrets' you may obtain around on every mission. Very often you travel between camps and villages, up and down rivers, across the jungle, and you are free to explore all of that. However, if you feel like visiting France instead of doing your objective, unfortunately, this hasn't been added yet.The only thing I noticed being odd was the bridge part in mission "A marksman at his best". In this mission, you do not carry a sniper, but binoculars and pistol as you are helping other sniper. But then comes the part where you have to run away from the enemies. Eventually, you come up to a bridge with 4-5 enemies on it, and you are supposed to go off the side of the bridge and into the river. However, for some reason, sometimes they notice you instantly and just destroy you, without giving you chance to go into water. It can be frustrating, but you may also just kill them all and continue on, so it is not a game crasher.Overall:This game is extremely underrated for some reason. Metascore should be at around at least 80 in my opinion. I have very much enjoyed this game, and for the price it has, it is really a good bargain. It has my recommendation.EDIT1:I wrote this review when I finished the campaign, but the content doesn't end there! After you finish campaign, you can go for Challange button and start playing totally new missions! Trick here is that you are taken all indicators, including health, bullet count and the tiny red circle that shows you exactly where the bullet will land. You are left to play with only your skill. Great game!

												Sniper: Ghost Warrior is an interesting little game. You could see what they were trying to do with it, but they didn't quite get there. To be fair, my first ever Sniper experience was slighty marred by the fact that the game isn't particularly compatible with win10 and the constant freezes, crashes and other little problems meant that my 14hr (twice as long as necessary) playthrough - from training to the end of unfinished business (dlc) - registered as about 25hrs on steam.  Pros: nice enough to look at on max settings;  the killcam never got tiring for me; it does mix up gameplay between sneaky sneaky and run and gun, with a couple of mounted shooting galleries thrown in for good measure.Cons: gameplay can get repetitive; sometimes (especially prone) the scenery is so in your face that you can't see anything beyond the foliage in front of your face, which ends in tears;  some of the shot/AI behaviour is truly laughable.TL:DR - fun little game, can get extremely annoying/frustrating at times and no end of problems if playing on anything beyond win7!Recommended only for patient people.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												Invisible walls: the gameThere's some fun to be had here, especially in multiplayer, but I can only recommend this one for a bargain price. The graphics are rather pretty and the game runs well on older PCs too but the actual game contained in the engine isn't that interesting. Level design is incredibly linear and punishes every urge to explore with plenty of invisible walls and telescope-vision enemies, that often spot you from a huge distance if you stray from the tiny path offered by the developers. The sniping itself is a lot of fun at times and adjustable to your comfort level, despite the AI but regular gunplay which unfortunately occurs too is a drag and discourages further playing. The story is of little help to keep you invested - even by the low standards of military shooters it's unengaging and keeps jumping back and forth between "characters" which I set in quotation marks because we never learn anything about the characters we are playing. I don't think I can even recall the name of the main character. Your main incentive as mr. soldier man is the voice in your head telling you to pop heads of south american baddies and after a while you kind of feel sympathy for the guys, since you, as the good guy, just show up with no authority, wreck their stuff and kill all their friends. It's somewhat feasible they might be the bad guys and it doesn't reach as far into the uncomfortable territory of the hyper-jingoistic splinter cell games but the story only has some shred of redeeming value if at the end it turns out you were part of a psychological experiment to determine how far you'd go if an authority figure tells you to.In conclusion, Sniper: Ghost Warrior isn't deep enough as a stealth game and not fluid enough as an fps, marred by restrictive level design and a tedious single player campaign, however the multiplayer can be incredibly fun if you're not confronted by expert players. There aren't that many maps and modes but I enjoyed it more than any other generic fps in recent memory. There's a lot of room for improvement and the game is not a trainwreck by any means, but still I can't recommend it, unless you love multiplayer and you can get it really cheap.

												This game is better than most general FPS's that include a sniper theme inside the actual game. Why? Because it's directly centered around the tactics and style protrayed by modern military sniper. This game displays a set of youth ranged ballistics and areodynamics, which does occasionally draw away from a true expierience. While it may feature bullet drop to some degree, that is the only true force that with be acting aginst where you hit your target. It fetures no windage, elevation change or temperature, etc. However, for the average person interested in this theme of military force, the game offers a great time. Still looking for a true sniper game though, but it's worth the buy if you are new to things like this. I highly recomend setting this on the "Hard" setting, as it gets rid of the red dot which allows for a much better expierience as a sniper.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												I don't know if I can recommend it, but I cannot say I do not recommend it.The game played fine.I started the game up and it has never quit on me in 50 hours.I alt tabbed for a couple days straight and a bunch of hours.The game took approximately 8 hours or so to complete. I am not too sure as I did reload a part where there was an error.So it's around 8-10 hours.I had the difficulty to the hardest possible.I didn't like the feel of it, although, I beat it with ease.The enemy sees you and you're automatically hit. It's not that they see you, it's more that, it's programmed to see you. You have a few other team mates around and they can stand there and not get hit at all.So you're constantly behind cover and pop out and go back and forth waiting to recharge to 30 health each time. There's really no point in the health pack, it's like 100% health and 30% is nearly alike.One of the missions where you had to kill one of the person doesn't work. Even if you kill him, he's still free. (it's not supposed to allow you to kill him, yet, you can)The sound is... okay I suppose. Directional sound you can hear. I did have issues with text, intro and the ending being upside down. It didn't, however, detract from the game as it played out normally. The multiplayer is extremely few. If you want to play this game for that reason, there's just no point.You'll also get many 4v2 and no one switching over to make it even. This happens way too many times, like 8 times nearly in a row a couple of days ago. As if, why wouldn't they make the game even? They are winning so why?So the community is not good.. Not good at all. They just do not care at all about it and want the game to die even more when it comes to multiplayer. So I guess, let it die. (Also, me being a new player to this, every one of the people are easy to kill, but when it is 4v2, it's not much you can really do)The ending was.... lackluster. It wasn't special, it didn't do anything. It just... ended.I didn't play any of the DLCs, I didn't feel as though they were worth getting.I would recommend at least playing it if you get it in a bundle. The price, well, I suppose it is okay.There is some enjoyments you can get out of this game. To be honest, I was hoping the game ended sooner for me. The AI is horrible. You can kill people right near em and they will not notice. Like, blood will splatter all over them(not really, since the blood doesn't stick on em) and they will just do nothing. So I guess, just play it if you have it or it is extremely cheap. Though, I wouldn't get it just to pick this game from a bundle. So, in essence, do I really recommend it?

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												A SIMPLE REVIEW: Only buy this game if you can get it for less than $5. No more. Best aspects are sniping, sneaking, and planning your shots/kills. While the sniping and sneaking are a lot of fun, the more "action" like parts are NOT! I recommend this only if you can grab it in a cheap bundle (I paid, mathematically speaking, less than $1 for this game). If you want more details, continue below.SNIPING/SNEAKING: A lot of fun, actually! Don't play this game on easy, just start it out on hard. You'll have a much more challenging and enjoyable experience. I had more than enough fun sneaking through the jungle and carefully picking my targets. Many enemies I had to leave behind in order to remain undetected. DO NOT PLAY THIS LIKE A RUN-AND-GUN! (as should be obvious) The mechanics of this game and your gear will not help you in the slightest and you will die easily. Which brings me, sadly, to the next part...NON-SNIPING PARTS: Due to the poor mechanics of this game and the overall design, the hardest, most annoying, and least fun parts were the ones where you have to use an assault rifle in a 3-man team. Recoil is terrible, accuracy is non-existant, and everyone else can take you out since they are shooting from all directions. Simply AWFUL! No other words needed to articulate this problem. Oh yeah, and the AI is either incredibly clueless or has the perception of a hawk, depending on your current status or location in a given mission. (sometimes the game just "automatically" made me detected even though I was never spotted and never raised an alert).I only recommend this game IF you buy it for less than $5. Otherwise, wait till the price drops. The sneaking and sniping through the jungle was a fun experience without a doubt and outweighs the terrible assault mechanics.

Posted: March 2, 2016
												A decent sniper game with decent bullet ballistics and a decent bulletcam.Would overall be a decent game if not for some really annoying bugs & glitches. These bugs & glitches include but are not limited to; - The player not being able to stay still on stairs- The enemies seeing you when they are not supposed - The enemies not seeing you when they are supposed to.- Too many unnecessary cutscenes.-Too many unnecessary mission objectives that are just f**king annoying after a point.Some Cons of this game also are;- Very linear gameplay.- Gets really boring after the first 3-4 missions. (Again, linear gameplay)- The automatic rifles are just ridicilous. I have never seen worst. (You'll see what I mean if you play the game)- In hard difficulty, it feels like all your enemies are veteran snipers who were born with the ability of sniping. They have no problem shooting you with a pistol from 200m. I mean sure, the game should be hard but not unrealistically hard. You can make the AI smarter or increase Damage taken or increase wind speed and change environmental factors, but if you are being hit by a pistol bullet from 200m away and almost dying from that shot, then that just makes the game stupid and annoying... Not "difficult".In short, Sniper: Ghost Warrior is an extremely average game. There is nothing special about it that makes it stand out. If you like sniper games in general and if stupid bugs, glitches and unnecessary things don't bother you, then you can try this game.I'd give it a 4/10.

												At first I thought this wasn't such a bad game. Not as bad as people made it out to be at least. I usually play games with an open mind. I don't want people to tell me which games are great and which games are not. If I had listened to these people I would've missed out on some pretty cool games. So, I started playing Sniper Ghost Warrior. First impressions; graphics are solid, gameplay as well. It reminded me of Sniper Elite, but set in the jungle. That was the first level. After a few levels, the AI started to get indecisive; at times hardly noticing you, and other times seeing you pretty much instantly, even when in cover. So the stealth aspect just wasn't there anymore, which is a shame because sneaking around and shooting people in slowmotion looked and felt great. Later levels also introduced run-and-gun aspects which just didn't fit the game. It didn't feel right and it didn't play right and should've been removed altogether.Let's just hope SGW 2 improves on most (all?) fronts.[Rating: 61/100]

I have already in advance completed this game on the Xbox 360 a long time ago, and to be honest I felt more connected into the game, and more sort a say “Alive” on the PC version. Here are some reasons why.1. With a decent good computer specifications, you can get amazing sniper experience. The graphics are stunning. As you would expect from the CryEngine. But It’s not quite the same visual quality as the Crysis games. Some areas look really nice, but others less so. Here is a screenshot captured by me in-game: http://imgur.com/IEv5urm Cut-scenes graphics are a bit poor, huge improvement can be done there, example: http://imgur.com/EpkAOPSI achieved much better fps after careful tweaking (Tip: Put “Object Detail” on low for massive fps boost and next to no quality loss).2. Having a headphone on you with Surround Sound makes you feel more realistic. I have tested it with speakers (Surround Sound), and I didn’t get nearly the same experience.3. I would recommend you to play it with a Xbox 360 controller on the PC version - (If it’s possible). Sniper Ghost Warrior it’s actually a more of a console type of game when it comes to controllers. Kinda like GTA V, The Witcher 3, and the Call of Duty franchise. And I’m not saying it because I played the game first with a Xbox 360, but the whole movement with a mouse and keyboard makes it feel weird compared to a smoother version with a controller. Controls are ok, but feel a bit clunky and are unresponsive in some contexts.4. Something I wasn’t aware of when I first played this game on the 360 console. I bought all of the DLC’s on the PC version, and I recognized the DLC called: Sniper Ghost Warrior 2: Digital Extras.The Special Edition Includes SOUNDTRACK - An official Soundtrack from the game’s musical score. It’s a nice soundtrack and has a nice beat to it in a close danger situation or a sticky situation. Your heart starts to beat a bit more and you get a little bit of the adrenaline kick. I think that’s a huge deal when it comes to sniper games.Sidenote: I think that Michał Cielecki did a amazing job with the soundtracks. I really feel excited when I hear his soundtracks. I’m looking forward to see if he have any soundtracks to the Sniper Ghost Warrior 3. https://soundcloud.com/michal-cieleckiGenerally about the game:It’s a good non-AAA game that provides a stealth and sniping experience. Presentation and writing are a bit clichéd, but I was already expecting this. Otherwise, the story is not bad at all. Levels are very linear and heavily scripted. You are guided by your commander who stays at your side most of the time. This provides good immersion and manages to convey the sense of working as a team.Cons/Improvements:I’m not going to cover every specific detail about this game, but I’m going to cover some of it.The scripting is fairly basic and lacks some polish. There were various issues. My AI was a bit unreliable when we went stealth mode - Here is actually a great example that I captured: http://imgur.com/D3hmFA6 On the picture you can see we were inside the tunnels in Bosnia Sarajevo. My teammate (Maddox) alerted me to hide because there were troops coming towards us. For some weird reason Maddox didn’t do anything (obviously he glitched out). After of certain of time Maddox starts yelling “♥♥♥♥! Run!!” when the guards are right in front of him. I had to restart my mission, because we were basically ♥♥♥♥ed when they had 10 guards pointing at us and firing. Lucky for me the checkpoint was right outside the tunnel. So I wasn’t needed to process the whole scenery (Before we went inside the tunnel again).Sometimes when you got the order/mission from either your teammate or your commander to go backstabbing a guard. You could just literally run behind him and make a lot of footsteps without him recognize anything. Seems like these guards are partly death at some areas. They only recognized you if they saw you and if you shoot. Hearing running footsteps and other small details like reloading a gun was not intended apparently.Dialogue were cutting off sometimes when you reached checkpoints.A few times my character would confirm over radio that I had the target in my sight, but the target was no where to be seen on my screen. The checkpoint save system has the usual irritations associated with such a system. Checkpoints was not reloading correctly.If you run down some stairs you just start floating a little bit above it instead of actually running on top of it. Kinda annoying effect http://imgur.com/sEyedLj. I also don’t like on the scene "Burning Bridges" (Act 3 - Mission 2) when you have to run from the temple and your stamina ends so often/quickly. Just like this: http://imgur.com/enuIHwO. I can understand that in reality it’s heavy carrying a sniper rifle around, but it’s kinda silly how Anderson survived there. In my opinion City Interactive could twisted this situation with other solutions.The simulation of wind on bullets feels artificial because the wind speed is not effectively reflected in the environment - vegetation does not respond accordingly and there are no other indicators like the sound of wind or moving dust etc. The displayed distances seem to be fake - an ingame distance of 400 meters is actually closer to 200 meters. http://imgur.com/IEv5urmBackdraw: If you just realized Sniper Ghost Warrior recently, I think you are going to be a bit disappointed in this game. Reason being is this game was released on March 12, 2013 in North America, March 15, 2013 in Europe and March 19, 2013 in Australia. They used not a old game engine to develop this game. But the singleplayer content is a bit slim compared to other games that are released in 2016. The game will approximately last 5 hours ish of gameplay. If you don’t care about these details that happens every now and then, and you are more into the main storyline in this game, I would recommend it. Be sure to follow some recommendations above to make this game even more enjoyable and I had very modest expectations, and it satisfied them. Get it when on sale.Rating:From 1-10. (8)Cannot wait to review Sniper Ghost Warrior 3 when the game is set to be released worldwide 4 Apr, 2017. http://imgur.com/N5JydFkSGW3:

content:
Posted: March 21
												First, two words...I really don't know what made me play this game in 2017. Probably out of boredom or stupidity...Also, I have no military expertise so excuse me if I make inaccurate assumptions.So... the game follows the adventures of a ninja-like sniper recon who can do pretty much everything. I don't know US Army/Navy/Marines/whatever very well, but I'm pretty sure they don't have this type of soldier in their ranks.I mean I understand I'm the hero of the story, but the game is set in real world. I imagine how those at HQ talk: "We need to protect some Deltas. Send the sniper. We need to destroy some plantations on some f...king islands. Send the sniper. We need to an entire army in South America. Hell, what the..., send the sniper."Oh, and some time the game feel the need to put you in one of the Delta guys... Then I realized why they need so much protection. From a team of three, two of them are immortal sponge bullets. The other one, of course, is the player. I couldn't rely on them because they, like me, have the accuracy of a blind bat. I mean, I could very well close my eyes and shoot - the result was the same.Problem is the game is scripted to play like this - those two drawing fire and I shooting the baddies. On one mission they decided "F..k it, we stay here!" and they didn't move on the map. Everyone shot at me. It was probably the longest mission in a game I ever played... and I play shooters since Wolfenstein 3D came out.It seems though this country in South America has the best soldiers in the world, at least regarding the accuracy. I never thought an AK-47 can hit me with almost all bullets fired from about 150-200 meters. I'd wish those Delta trained with these guys...Missions are designed by someone with a death wish or at least masochistic. At some point the chopper sent for extraction couldn't take me away because LZ was too hot. Of course, as in every war movie, there was another LZ where I was pointed to. "Ok, buddy, we can't get you out now, but go to the second LZ which is deep inside enemy territory!" WTF? Say again? Who the hell picked that spot? Oh, and I need to clear the LZ? Why the hell I can't clear the first one, right here, right now?So, this is what you should expect from it.No, just no.Sorry for my bad English.

content:
Posted: February 22
												Alright, I’m here to answer some questions you may thinking to yourself. Is it worth buying it? Is this game fun?Beaware of some of it might be spoiler alert.Personally so far I think this is the best game CI Games have produced. As a sniper-enthusiast I look for pros and cons with this game. I have already in advance completed this game on the Xbox 360 a long time ago, and to be honest I felt more connected into the game, and more sort a say “Alive” on the PC version. Here are some reasons why.1. With a decent good computer specifications, you can get amazing sniper experience. The graphics are stunning. As you would expect from the CryEngine. But It’s not quite the same visual quality as the Crysis games. Some areas look really nice, but others less so. Here is a screenshot captured by me in-game: http://imgur.com/IEv5urm Cut-scenes graphics are a bit poor, huge improvement can be done there, example: http://imgur.com/EpkAOPSI achieved much better fps after careful tweaking (Tip: Put “Object Detail” on low for massive fps boost and next to no quality loss).2. Having a headphone on you with Surround Sound makes you feel more realistic. I have tested it with speakers (Surround Sound), and I didn’t get nearly the same experience.3. I would recommend you to play it with a Xbox 360 controller on the PC version - (If it’s possible). Sniper Ghost Warrior it’s actually a more of a console type of game when it comes to controllers. Kinda like GTA V, The Witcher 3, and the Call of Duty franchise. And I’m not saying it because I played the game first with a Xbox 360, but the whole movement with a mouse and keyboard makes it feel weird compared to a smoother version with a controller. Controls are ok, but feel a bit clunky and are unresponsive in some contexts.4. Something I wasn’t aware of when I first played this game on the 360 console. I bought all of the DLC’s on the PC version, and I recognized the DLC called: Sniper Ghost Warrior 2: Digital Extras.The Special Edition Includes SOUNDTRACK - An official Soundtrack from the game’s musical score. It’s a nice soundtrack and has a nice beat to it in a close danger situation or a sticky situation. Your heart starts to beat a bit more and you get a little bit of the adrenaline kick. I think that’s a huge deal when it comes to sniper games.Sidenote: I think that Michał Cielecki did a amazing job with the soundtracks. I really feel excited when I hear his soundtracks. I’m looking forward to see if he have any soundtracks to the Sniper Ghost Warrior 3. https://soundcloud.com/michal-cieleckiGenerally about the game:It’s a good non-AAA game that provides a stealth and sniping experience. Presentation and writing are a bit clichéd, but I was already expecting this. Otherwise, the story is not bad at all. Levels are very linear and heavily scripted. You are guided by your commander who stays at your side most of the time. This provides good immersion and manages to convey the sense of working as a team.Cons/Improvements:I’m not going to cover every specific detail about this game, but I’m going to cover some of it.The scripting is fairly basic and lacks some polish. There were various issues. My AI was a bit unreliable when we went stealth mode - Here is actually a great example that I captured: http://imgur.com/D3hmFA6 On the picture you can see we were inside the tunnels in Bosnia Sarajevo. My teammate (Maddox) alerted me to hide because there were troops coming towards us. For some weird reason Maddox didn’t do anything (obviously he glitched out). After of certain of time Maddox starts yelling “♥♥♥♥! Run!!” when the guards are right in front of him. I had to restart my mission, because we were basically ♥♥♥♥ed when they had 10 guards pointing at us and firing. Lucky for me the checkpoint was right outside the tunnel. So I wasn’t needed to process the whole scenery (Before we went inside the tunnel again).Sometimes when you got the order/mission from either your teammate or your commander to go backstabbing a guard. You could just literally run behind him and make a lot of footsteps without him recognize anything. Seems like these guards are partly death at some areas. They only recognized you if they saw you and if you shoot. Hearing running footsteps and other small details like reloading a gun was not intended apparently.Dialogue were cutting off sometimes when you reached checkpoints.A few times my character would confirm over radio that I had the target in my sight, but the target was no where to be seen on my screen. The checkpoint save system has the usual irritations associated with such a system. Checkpoints was not reloading correctly.If you run down some stairs you just start floating a little bit above it instead of actually running on top of it. Kinda annoying effect http://imgur.com/sEyedLj. I also don’t like on the scene "Burning Bridges" (Act 3 - Mission 2) when you have to run from the temple and your stamina ends so often/quickly. Just like this: http://imgur.com/enuIHwO. I can understand that in reality it’s heavy carrying a sniper rifle around, but it’s kinda silly how Anderson survived there. In my opinion City Interactive could twisted this situation with other solutions.The simulation of wind on bullets feels artificial because the wind speed is not effectively reflected in the environment - vegetation does not respond accordingly and there are no other indicators like the sound of wind or moving dust etc. The displayed distances seem to be fake - an ingame distance of 400 meters is actually closer to 200 meters. http://imgur.com/IEv5urmBackdraw: If you just realized Sniper Ghost Warrior recently, I think you are going to be a bit disappointed in this game. Reason being is this game was released on March 12, 2013 in North America, March 15, 2013 in Europe and March 19, 2013 in Australia. They used not a old game engine to develop this game. But the singleplayer content is a bit slim compared to other games that are released in 2016. The game will approximately last 5 hours ish of gameplay. If you don’t care about these details that happens every now and then, and you are more into the main storyline in this game, I would recommend it. Be sure to follow some recommendations above to make this game even more enjoyable and I had very modest expectations, and it satisfied them. Get it when on sale.Rating:From 1-10. (8)Cannot wait to review Sniper Ghost Warrior 3 when the game is set to be released worldwide 4 Apr, 2017. http://imgur.com/N5JydFkSGW3:

Posted: March 20, 2016
												This game was only average - 6/10 at best when it was released.  It hasn't aged well, and the things that were annoying about it 6 years ago are only magnified in this age.While a million miles better than CI Games previous effort at the genre - the woeful Sniper Art of Victory - it still falls short of a pleasant FPS experience.  The somewhat satisfying sniping elements are held back by an AI that doesn't know if it's on God mode or stormtrooper mode, while the infantry parts of the game are held back by the fundamentally broken assault rifles that the game gives those characters.AI can detect you seemingly for no reason as you are in cover, they can sometimes care if you kill their buddies 5 feet away and otherwise not.  At one point I took a break from a mission to shoot birds with an unsilanced rifle, then when I carried on realised there had been a 3 man patrol not 30 feet away that was still in "oblivious" mode.The feeling of achievement of pulling off a hit with your rifle, taking into account bullet drop due to gravity and wind direction is cheapend somewhat when your enemies can hit you with pinpoint precision using their assault rifles at the same distance.  These are the same assault rifles you will struggle to use, as the kick and spread is extreme to the point of uselessness.Manual saving is encouraged with this game, the chekpoints aren't always in places you would expect and can indeed just put you into a loop of spawn-die-spawn-die.At least CI Games paid for some proper voice talent this time round - but the story they are telling is very cliche.You'll have more fun with Sniper Elite 2 if you want to play a sniper game- I promise you.

												I know a lot of people say this game is bad and buggy and it's fairly old, but I would reccomend it. The graphics and bugs are pretty bad. More than half of the enemies start running against a wall half the time and won't stop unless you shoot them. Also, you can put your gun and arm through almost anything, including trees and buildings. But, the gameplay is really good. The game is a lot like Sniper Elite, including that you can slow everything down to control your breathing, and there's a red dot below the crosshair you have to aim for, and that it zooms in on a lot of kills. It's also not all sniping. There is a lot of missions where you'll have assault rifles and no snipers. But the point of the game is all about just killing enemies, it's about being stealth and then taking perfect shots while hidden. There's also a lot of cutscenes and story. It's not the best game ever, especially because of the bugs, but for 8 dollars, it's worth it.

Posted: April 30, 2016
												I was originally finding at least some fun in this game at the start, so my orinigal review, despite being more of a "meh" kind of situation, was going to be positive. That said, having finished the game in just over 4 hours and 30 minutes (Steam claims 6, but that's likely due to leaving the game running while doing other things away from my computer) and finding merit in the complaints of others, I think a negative mark would suffice.The AI can genuinely range from dumber than a sack of hammers to eagle-eyed geniouses, and they are indeed somehow more accurate with hipfire than the player can be while looking down the scope/iron sights of their rifle. While I somewhat appreciated the change of pace from sneeki breeki sniping to run-and-gun action, I'm left scratching my head as to why the latter was even added in a game that, if you were to go by the title alone, would/should be about sniping and stealth. And on that note, the sniping isn't even satisfying! How do you mess that up?I had hoped to go through the "Unfinished Business" storyline after completing this game, but now I'm not so sure it would be wise to do so, even with the supposed "revamped AI." All I can say is I'm glad I bought this on sale in a bundle, so now that I can honestly say I've played this, I can now move on to the (hopefully superior) sequel.

I played the actual game for ~5 minutes, once I found a way to get it to lauch properly. Let me regail you all with a story.            Once upon a time there was a man who had seen a game that looked good and was on sale. The man goes out and buys a Steam card to purchase said game, he even went and picked up a slightly better graphics card. He comes home to his wife and children, they are awaiting his return eagerly. He picks up his daughter and messes up his sons hair, then he kisses his wife. He was so excited to finally get a new game to play in his free time.            He goes onto the Steam store, and there he sees it. Sniper: Ghost Warrior. He adds it to his cart and checks out. He was amazed at the download speed, for surely a good FPS would not be such a blazing download. This was the first flag.The man, with hope still flowing out of his heart like the river Isen into Isengard, presses the "Play" button and waits.1 minute and the game had not loaded. He thought that it was just the game having that 1st boot-up speed.He was wrong.5 minutes in and the game still had not loaded. He began to wonder if the game was going to load at all.7 minutes in and the game had crashed. At this point the man was becoming upset, so he went to bed and left the game to be dealt with another day.Weeks and months pass without a second of the mans play time spent on this game, the game had become a shelf-sitter. One day, the man decided to try to play the game again. He pressed "Play" and the game actually booted! The man was ecstatic! The game for which he had been hyped for so long ago was finally working!!Thats when it happened. The game introduced the man into a well sculpted world, with enemies speaking in foreign tongues and sniper rifles with scrim all around them. It was, for a short time, beautiful. The man eagerly got into a firefight, and then the worst thing happened. The mechanics were broken; hit detection, scoped accuracy, sound suppression, stealth mechanics and everything about the game. As he was sniping the skrubs like a boss, the man was shot; much like what would happen if one man was trying to take on 100+ enemies. The game crashed.The man was furious that after so long, and so much hype, the game still would not function.The man later became very depressed; took up drinking and smoking. His wife later divorced him and took the children into her custody.The man lost his house and his job.All of this simply because this game is so broken. Made a man get divorced, lose his children, his house, and his dog.10/10 Manic Depression Simulator 2010.

All I can say is I'm glad I bought this on sale in a bundle, so now that I can honestly say I've played this, I can now move on to the (hopefully superior) sequel.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												TLDR:  Good game, good gameplay, decent challenge, runs solid with no performance issues.  At the time this came out, it was the first good sniper game in a long time.  It is worth picking up today on a discount if you are looking for a good shooter that allows you to be a little slower paced & strategic while scratching that sniper itch.The game is not about run & gun, and while occasionally you get spotted & have to "OH SH*T" your way out of things a bit with guns-a-blazing, the main method for maneuvering through this game is via the art of stealth.  It actually makes you TRY to act like a sniper.  You will benefit greatly from things like cover, and careful movements that reduce noise, while devising the optimal method by which to complete your mission.  And whether you choose to take out all your enemies one by one, or perhaps instead to move stealthily around them without killing a single one, you will find some challenge to it either way.Something this game gets absolutely right and does very well is the ballistics.  The manner in which your bullet trajectory will be altered once it is fired, and how things like wind, gravity, distance, and objects will affect the path of the bullet on the way to it's target, or the impact it makes once it hits.  One recommendation however, is that you should play the game on "HARD" mode.  The "EASY" & "NORMAL" modes are virtually the same, and they both provide an "aim assist" function that basically puts a little circle on the screen that tells you exactly where your bullet will hit regardless of conditions.  This is still fun to play as you get the "thrll of the kill" just the same, but it makes the game a little too easy.If you play in HARD mode, it will remove the "aim-assist" function, and you will have to calculate the trajectory of the bullet yourself by reading the wind speed & gauge the distance to your target, etc.  It is not really that hard to do, but it provides for a GREAT challenge, and REALLY elevates the excitement and interest in the game.  It's a fun feeling when you're really sweating it out over having to make this ONE shot on a high-value target really count, and missing could be the end of YOU instead.  But it's an AWESOME feeling when you put a bullet through that enemy sniper's scope at 1100 yards in high wind, and you did it all by your own calculations!The game has a decent storyline that isn't too shocking, but has a few plot twists here & there.  Enough at least to push the missions forward with a decent amount of variety, and without getting boring or repetitive.  You might not get heavily invested into any of the characters, but that's not really what you're here for anyway.  Even still there are a few moments of satisfaction when you see a few particular guys get what's coming to them.There are a few moments where the AI is a bit... let's see... I believe "special" is the PC term nowadays, right?  Ya, sometimes, the AI will have their comrade slump to the deck with a hole in his chest a mere 10 feet away and not notice it, but then other times you take out a guy 50 yards away from another and he'll see it happen & hit the alarm.  It's a bit annoying, but you'll eventually get the feel for it and shouldn't have much trouble if you play it smart & be patient.  There's ALWAYS a perfect opportunity.Not much happening in the multiplayer nowadays, but that's to be expected with this being such an old game.  It's still fun however if you can fire it up with a few buddies & take turns rag-dolling each other.Overall I'd have given this game an 8/10 when it first came out.  Nowadays there ARE better options, so I'd say 7/10 overall now.  Still, very much worth the buy when you can have it on the cheap nowadays with it always being on sale.ONE LAST WARNING:  You might be tempted to purchase "Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2" either along with or instead of this one.  I will say that while the second installment in the series is far better in the graphics department, it is TERRIBLE in the reliability department.  I suggest you read the reviews on all the bugs & issues with that game before making your purchase.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												This game was best when it first came out. I have great memories of multiplayer matches in the first few days after release when no one realized yet that the radar shows you exactly where your enemies are.Let me explain. This game does a fantastic job at making you invisible with camouflage. Its the best I've ever seen in a game. You blend in with your environment like crazy and I had several occassions where a player in multiplayer would stand right in front of me (sitting in a bush) and still not see me. Thats what made these first few days so great. You would sit in your sniper spot on a big map and try to find other, super camouflaged snipers and try to shoot them. The matches were intense and interesting. Soon it became apparent that you have a radar that shows you where your enemies are. The dev said this is to prevent camping. For real? This is a sniper game!The singleplayer missions are complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. A mix between bad stealth missions and just a tad too much narrative when it comes to the interesting sniper bits. The multiplayer would be insanely great if that damn radar was removed. Im serious. If you didn't know where your enemies are in multiplayer this would probably be my most played game. This isn't about wanting to be a camper or whatever. Get a few friends to play this game and agree with everyone to not use the radar (hang a piece of paper over it -  yes I know...) and you will see what I mean.I'm giving this a thumbs up because I haven't seen another sniper game yet that makes you blend in with your enviroment like this one does. However I wish the devs would have gone a different direction with the multiplayer. What a wasted oppurtunity!

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												TLDR:  Good game, good gameplay, decent challenge, runs solid with no performance issues.  At the time this came out, it was the first good sniper game in a long time.  It is worth picking up today on a discount if you are looking for a good shooter that allows you to be a little slower paced & strategic while scratching that sniper itch.The game is not about run & gun, and while occasionally you get spotted & have to "OH SH*T" your way out of things a bit with guns-a-blazing, the main method for maneuvering through this game is via the art of stealth.  It actually makes you TRY to act like a sniper.  You will benefit greatly from things like cover, and careful movements that reduce noise, while devising the optimal method by which to complete your mission.  And whether you choose to take out all your enemies one by one, or perhaps instead to move stealthily around them without killing a single one, you will find some challenge to it either way.Something this game gets absolutely right and does very well is the ballistics.  The manner in which your bullet trajectory will be altered once it is fired, and how things like wind, gravity, distance, and objects will affect the path of the bullet on the way to it's target, or the impact it makes once it hits.  One recommendation however, is that you should play the game on "HARD" mode.  The "EASY" & "NORMAL" modes are virtually the same, and they both provide an "aim assist" function that basically puts a little circle on the screen that tells you exactly where your bullet will hit regardless of conditions.  This is still fun to play as you get the "thrll of the kill" just the same, but it makes the game a little too easy.If you play in HARD mode, it will remove the "aim-assist" function, and you will have to calculate the trajectory of the bullet yourself by reading the wind speed & gauge the distance to your target, etc.  It is not really that hard to do, but it provides for a GREAT challenge, and REALLY elevates the excitement and interest in the game.  It's a fun feeling when you're really sweating it out over having to make this ONE shot on a high-value target really count, and missing could be the end of YOU instead.  But it's an AWESOME feeling when you put a bullet through that enemy sniper's scope at 1100 yards in high wind, and you did it all by your own calculations!The game has a decent storyline that isn't too shocking, but has a few plot twists here & there.  Enough at least to push the missions forward with a decent amount of variety, and without getting boring or repetitive.  You might not get heavily invested into any of the characters, but that's not really what you're here for anyway.  Even still there are a few moments of satisfaction when you see a few particular guys get what's coming to them.There are a few moments where the AI is a bit... let's see... I believe "special" is the PC term nowadays, right?  Ya, sometimes, the AI will have their comrade slump to the deck with a hole in his chest a mere 10 feet away and not notice it, but then other times you take out a guy 50 yards away from another and he'll see it happen & hit the alarm.  It's a bit annoying, but you'll eventually get the feel for it and shouldn't have much trouble if you play it smart & be patient.  There's ALWAYS a perfect opportunity.Not much happening in the multiplayer nowadays, but that's to be expected with this being such an old game.  It's still fun however if you can fire it up with a few buddies & take turns rag-dolling each other.Overall I'd have given this game an 8/10 when it first came out.  Nowadays there ARE better options, so I'd say 7/10 overall now.  Still, very much worth the buy when you can have it on the cheap nowadays with it always being on sale.ONE LAST WARNING:  You might be tempted to purchase "Sniper: Ghost Warrior 2" either along with or instead of this one.  I will say that while the second installment in the series is far better in the graphics department, it is TERRIBLE in the reliability department.  I suggest you read the reviews on all the bugs & issues with that game before making your purchase.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2012
												Sniper: Ghost Warrior is on the surface a first person stealth shooter with attractive graphics but it doesn't take long for the flaws to become readily apparent.  While the game does have servicable graphics, the campaign missions are short, terribly linear and scripted and feature some of the worst enemy AI I have ever encountered in the genre.  You can literally shoot one of two adjacent enemies, and the other will act as if nothing has happened.  The enemies in the vicinity show up on the mini map in red, making taking most of them out a trivial matter.  The stealth is also poorly implemented, with foliage being opaque to the player, meaning a single blade of grass can completely obscure your view.  Add to that audio that seems to pan all around you giving no indication of enemy whereabouts and you are left with a disaster of a game.  Avoid this title.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												06-Jun-2016 : Finished main story + extrasEquipment : MSI GT80-2QE NotebookREVIEW :This could be a fun sniping game, but it is badly broken by bugs. Frame drops to 1 FPS everytime NPC open fire, scope crosshair missing vertical line and unable to display variable zoom, invisible text in menu, up-side-down video. This game is barely playable on my PC and the only way I'm able to finish it is by using certain "method".The story is corny and short. The gameplay is a mix between stealth using sniper rifle and action using assault rifle, so it's not pure sniper experience as I'm expected it to be.This game uses Chrome Engine and Call of Juarez series (which also uses the same engine) has the same problems (missing texture, frame drops, invisible menu, up-side-down video, etc). So I deduce that the problem is the engine itself, not the game coding. Fortunately I got this game really cheap and the Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 that came bundled with this game run perfectly fine. FYI, Sniper Ghost Warrior 2 uses Cry Engine 3 and I recommend it instead this one.CONCLUSION :Not recommended.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2012
												The moment I started the game, my jaw dropped in awe. If there is one thing Sniper: Ghost Warrior should be remembered for, it'd be its lush, beautiful, tropical setting. Graphically, this game has it down pat. Sadly, the same cannot be said for anything else.The campaign takes you into the lives of a deadly marksman and a trained soldier who are hot on the trail of an elusive weapons dealer. The switches between two characters are the game's poor attempts to add variety.Ghost Warrior is already a subpar game with sporadic A.I. behavior and some nonsensical design choices. Unfortunately, it gets worse during the infantry missions. The gunplay is atrocious and regenerating health saps the excitement of combat.The game's saving grace is twofold. There are few games quite like Sniper. Despite its flaws, there's still fun to be had. And of course: its stealth missions. Nothing is more rewarding than sneaking past an entire platoon of soldiers or picking them off from afar.Grade: C-
