												I read the reviews and as suggested, only bought the game when it was a Steam daily special for 5 USD. I played the game on normal difficulty and have to say that most of the reviews are misleading. This game is highly underrated. I thoroughly enjoyed it. It took me 9 hours to complete the single player game. The graphics are fantastic, but you will need a decent machine to play it on the higher settings. I did not experience any problems with AI over reacting. If you take your time, move slowly and stay hidden, you won't have any issues. If anything I must agree that the AI sometimes under reacts e.g. not getting a reaction from a guy when you have just taken down the guy standing next to him. There are many factors you have to consider when playing this game. Are you using a suppressor or will the AI hear your gun? Is the AI facing you when you make a dash across the path or road? Do you change position when your cover is blown? The quick save feature is very useful. I was caught a few times and after trying a different approach, managed to get through.I enjoyed the few missions where I had to use an assault rifle. It added a nice change to the game. The pistol and knife were useful in close quarters situations. I hardly used the grenades. I also enjoyed the mix of sniper rifles you get to play with. I loved the fact that you can shoot through small gaps in walls and fences as well as through vegetation.I have started the game again on hard difficulty, which has no assists and presents a whole new challenge. I can't wait!I would give the game a 10, but there were definitely a few issues with it. The game as a whole far outweighs the glitches and I highly recommend it to FPS gamers who enjoy the satisfaction of a successful sniper shot. It is definitely one of my favourites.

												Trash trash trash. That's all this is.Graphics are about as generic as it gets when it comes to FPS games. Definitely not up to par with other games released at the same time. This is clearly visible in screenshots and videos. However, I've never really been one to harp on graphics, let's move on to game play.The idea behind this game seems to be, make it as easy as possible and hold the players hand. Follow this guy, get to this way point, kill this character. I might as well have been on rails the whole time. And if that wasn't easy enough, they make sniping a joke. Yeah, there's wind and bullet drop and blah blah blah, but we're going to give you a little circle that will tell you where the bullet goes so you don't have to think. Just move where we tell you and shoot who we tell you.The stealth system is just as bad. I sat outside a bush and an enemy patrol just walked on by. Not noticing me at all. The hardest part was when I had to kill a group across a bridge and one enemy ai apparently had super aimbot with instagib. Easy enough, just hang back and shoot him right? Wrong, I only had a pistol. So I had to just spam bullets at him until I ran out of ammo, run out and die to reload the check point just to do it again until I killed him.The ending is horrible. Very abrupt and anti-climactic. Shoot the guy, roll credits.If you're looking for something to kill time, this may be worth it if you can pick it up in a cheap bundle. Definitely would not recommend it for full price.

												Picked this up for $5 on the Steam Holiday Sale. Was it worth it? For $5, I would say yes. Sniper: Ghost Warrior is an actioned filled sniper shooter that focuses on trying to provide realistic sniper combat as well as stealth. This game achieves at being fairly entertaining, enough so to keep me playing through the campaign. The storyline is decent, while predicatable at times. The level design was pretty good as a whole, and while the environments and scenery are quite beautiful, the game does feel very linear. That being said, most maps and missions do have some open areas and provide room to explore should you wish to do so. This game does have some major shortcomings nonetheless: it overall doesn't feel as polished as it could be, the voice acting is decent but the dialogue for enemies loops and isn't varied enough, the game has bugs and rendering issues, the AI is unbalanced, and I didn't find that the sniping realism was fully achieved. We'll see if the sequel improves upon this franchise.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2011
												Sniper: Ghost Warrior gets a bad rap from most reviewers. Personally I steer clear from most of the generic realistic big name FPS titles so I am rating this based on it's own merits as a sniper. While probably devised using some random Tom Clancy name generator, it is actually a fun game. It does have it's flaws, occasional bugs (Nothing gamebreaking) and over sensitive AI but in essence it is a realistic, highly satisfying sniper/stealth simulator. Each perfectly aimed headshot is rewarding with a slow motion camera following the bullet until the evil generic mexican soldier falls to the ground with his hat flying off. The graphics give the illusion of a crysis competitor through fancy shaders and choppy shadows but are impressive for a much lower budget title. A fun campaign mode, as you can guess multiplayer is just a giant campfest waiting for someone to move. Don't pay more than $10 or $15 for it though if you value your money.

												I kinda only have complains about this game:The graphics are not very good, even for the time when this game was released, the controls are kinda weird too, specially when your character is using an assault weapon instead of the sniper rifle, also there's no real consistency as to when the NPCs notice you when you're trying to sneak into camps, sometimes they do when you're actually hidden and sometimes you can pretty much walk past by then in plain sight when they should see you.You can't run very long unless you want your character to pretty much start having an asthma attack, same goes when you're trying to snipe, your character is breathing too hard and sometime you have to use the 'hold your breath' function to make a good shoot, I know this is supposed to give a realistic spin to the game play but it gets annoying after a while. content:
Posted: October 12, 2012
												If you are the kind of guy that always gravitates towards sniper rifles in any and every game you get your hands on then Sniper: Ghost Warrior is for you. It is a sniper's paradise with a campaign finely crafted for epic long shots. You may not find yourself too deeply embroiled in the rather bland story or the so-so voice acting and writing but you will ache for the next moment that you get the chance to line up a bad guy in your scope. This effect is intensified by the harder levels of difficulty that add in things like windage and elevation and lack a helper diamond that lets you know where to aim. It goes from being a game to an art form and a true sniper will feel right at home. If you are not a born sniper then this game is a solid "meh" you will have fun but not as much. The multiplayer is more of an afterthought and as aforementioned the campaign is really just a sniper sandbox with some story thrown in. Also the bullet time function is cool but not Sniper Elite V2 quality.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Good: -Decent graphics (lush jungle, beach water, etc.)-First part is actual sniper stuff (sneak around, stealth, pick off enemies from distance)-Liked the bullet view from Sniper Art of Victory (camera focuses on bullet flight). Bad: Oh boy here we go.... Somewhere early in the game you get switched out to play an operator who has an M4 and you assault a rig in close quarters then assault a village/base on a beach. Here are the problems.-You are not playing as a sniper anymore.-Enemies hit you hard (25-30 per hit)-Even just  a little peek will get you hit-Enemies have pinpoint accuracy (No time to line up a shot)-You only have iron sights-The other weapons you can take from dead enemies only have iron sights too-The sniper you played earlier who is on a lighthouse isn't even helping you-Friendly AI in your team are just standing aroundIndividually, these points would not be a deal breaker for me. But if I only have iron sights and enemies have almost instantaneous reaction time and hit almost a third of your health, which is very limited, then the compounding of those are just too much.I wouldn't recommend this game because I was looking for a sniper game. But you're forced to play a level (probably more levels) where you're not a sniper and it's very, very, frustrating.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												- Sniper Ghost Warrior - After having completed this game, I believe it deserves a review. So here it is:Sniper Ghost Warrior is a Sniping FPS, made by City Interactive. You play as a small US Military unit, which consists of several members. The one you'll be playing in about 75% of the missions is Sergeant Tyler Wells, known as 'Razor Six Four.' He is the Sniper of his unit and in an unbelievable turn of events, you'll be doing most of the sniping in the game as this guy. The game has an interesting way of interpreting each squad member's role, as since you'll be doing most of the sniping as Sergeant Wells, you'll also get to play as the Spotter, O'Neil, in which you'll have to help out Wells in picking targets to snipe through your binoculars. You can also play as a couple members of a Ground Assault Team where most of the gunfighting is done, but I'll get to that in a minute.I'd like to keep this review simple by first covering the game itself, then the different gameplay aspects you'll be diving into throughout the campaign.First off, the game itself looks really pretty for a 2010 release. The foilage and jungles look lush and thick, and well rendered, and the buildings in the urban areas all look convincing and well modeled. The draw distance is very far (which I would expect from a game which focuses on shooting people at extreme range) and the lighting is impressive. On the other hand though, the character models look pretty bland and even look like plastic up-close. The enemies throughout the game literally have about four different models and the animation isn't great. Enemies won't do things such as take cover, instead preferring to stand in the open and shoot right at you, despite the range disadvantage, which leads me to another issue.The AI are either omnipotent or brain-dead. Sometimes they will be doing the sniping with bursts from their rifles, killing you very quickly and being able to see you from a country mile away, or they'll look about in horror having seen their pal collapse from a .45ACP to the head, even though you'll be standing right behind them as they panic. They never do anything other than shoot or throw grenades at you, and on missions where detection = failure, some may raise the alarm as they die - despite having nobody nearby to see or hear them die. They'll gladly stand still as you shoot them up, trying to return fire.One of the features of Sniper Ghost Warrior affect your ballistics, or in non-sniper jargon, how your rounds travel over a distance. You'll have to account for bullet drop and lead your targets, and ensure you keep your heartbeat at a low BPM to maintain optimal accuracy. You can use the Mil-Dots on your scope to ensure kills at longer ranges, or the chevrons on a PSO scope. The issue is however, most of the sniping isn't done at a long enough range to even need to adjust your shot. You'll be trying harder to stay undetected, and if you're like me, you'll be relying more on your sidearm to eliminate sentries and slip past. A feature which also bugged me was that on both the Easy and Medium difficulties, a little red circle will appear on your scope to tell you EXACTLY WHERE TO AIM, which pretty much renders most of what I've mentioned in this paragraph redundant. Having discovered that this circle is disabled in the Hardest difficulty, I immediately restarted and went for this option. Things were better then, and it was more enjoyable for sure, but with increasing the difficulty, another problem surfaced...Remember when I said the AI were sometimes omnipotent and could spot you anywhere? On Hard, you'll be utter screwed if luck isn't on your side, as you'll literally be one-dinked from No Mans Land by a kiddie conscript in his early twenties if you don't see him first. It's pure Rocket-Tag gameplay, and whoever gets the first shot in usually wins the fight. This wouldn't be an issue if the game was completely stealth. You'll have scripted events where you'll have to retreat under fire, and if the game rolls a 'Screw You' on the dice of fate, you'll die instantly and will have to try again, regardless of what you do otherwise. I remember on the chapter 'Steal From Under Their Noses', where as soon as you grab the intel, you'll be compromised, and forced to swim to safety. Two guards will spawn behind you after you start swimming, which will nine times out of ten, kill you while you're defenceless. I had to repeat this part countless times, before I managed to escape. I had a similar issue later in the game when I was playing as the Spotter, and only had a MK.23 (A .45ACP Handgun) with abysmal range to defend myself. I had to sneak past a bridge, but the guards seen me nearly every time and I was shredded. I couldn't fight back as my MK.23 just couldn't hit them at the range I was at.Now, referring back to the other characters, you'll be playing as the Ground Assault Team in some chapters. This is where the game often turns to mud. The gunplay is horrible and any weapon will have ridiculous recoil and shake more than a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dog. There is no stealth at all and you'll have to make do with only a few weapons to fight your way through. There are very few weapons in the game at all, with most of them being Sniper Rifles, naturally, so at these points you'll only have a few AR's and maybe a USAS-12 to hand to get by, all of which suck. You'll still have the never-missing AI blast you to bits though, and an occasional dose of 3 to 4 grenades being hurled at you at once. You play as these guys in more than one chapter too. The Spotter, O'Neil's missions are brief but rather lacklustre. Simply consisting of marking targets though a set of binoculars for the aforementioned Wells to snipe. (I suppose it's more realistic than the rest of the game). Chances are you'll be here for Wells' missions, which ARE the sniping aspect of the sniping game. Previous issues apply and you'll often be potshotting rookies from less than 100 metres away, nullifying the whole point of having a Sniper there in the first place. You'd be as well sending Solid Snake. You can pick up enemy weapons but they're as jerky and inaccurate as playing as the Ground Assault Team, once again ruining the purpose of being a Sniper to begin with.The story is pretty generic, with the US finding another dictator that doesn't like them much, a la Castro, so they send your team in to liquidate them.  You mess up, he gets away, big escapade, you rescue an Agent, they double-cross you, generic rebels save your♥♥♥♥♥(who you see ONCE and they are never seen nor heard from again). You find out they want to free their mates (VIVA LA REVOLUCION) who are being forced to work in a Uranium mine for the big bad. You go in, 'Murica style, blow their♥♥♥♥♥♥up, return to the original mission of assasinating the Head Gringo, do so...  AND THE GAME ENDS RIGHT THERE. RIGHT AFTER YOU TAKE THE FINAL SHOT. What. The. Hell. (It literally fades to black, 'THE END' appears, credits roll.) Well wasn't all that build up for nothing or what?!To put an end to this review, I'd have to say first that I got this game in a bundle. I may not have bought it otherwise but after having played it I would have to say that it isn't worth your time, unless you get it in a bundle yourself or get it very cheap. It wasn't a huge studio that made the game, fair enough, but I feel as though they make their own game pointless by giving you Assault Rifles at any time, and telling you where your bullet will land. It is, as I said, very pretty to look at, but not much to it. A 4-5 hour campaign at most and dead multiplayer. If sniping is your bag and you can't get enough of it, I recommend to get this and play it on the Hardest difficulty from the get-go. You'll still get absolutely mullered at the scripted events where stealth is not an option (more common they should be), but at least it'll provide a challenging experience. Aim high.

Posted: June 27, 2016
												Sniper: Ghost Warrior makes a rough but sort of charming first impression. Using the Chrome 4 engine originally featured in Call of Juarez: Bound in Blood in 2009, Sniper bears a fair bit of resemblance to last year's video game western, except for, well, all those trees and bushes. While character models look rough around the edges, the environments appear expansive and lush. What's more striking is the sniping mechanic itself. While Sniper: Ghost Warrior isn't quite as excruciatingly prone to realism as, say, ARMA 2 or the original Operation: Flashpoint, it seems realistic. Shots from the titular sniper rifles in Ghost Warrior are subject to gravity and environmental effects from wind and the like, such that play is predicated less on twitch gunplay and more on setting up and taking the right shots at targets - at least at first.

												This game is very much underated! Apart from a few very minor gameplay issues that aen't even worth mentioning...this is a solid game! All those comments about the title screen being updside down are true, but the menus are all right side up so who really cares that the background artwork is upside down on a title or menu screen...not me! Gameplay is not affected so really...why waste your time trying to fix that stuff?? The difficulty levels offer just that..varied difficulties. I really enjoyed the DLC missions... especially The Last Hunt..with the minimal HUD and the more intuitive AI...I really had to play smart to avoid getting whacked! The fact you couldn't save game added to that more realistic level of play! not to worry though, there are checkpoints... so if you do get whacked (and you will) you don't have to go back to the start of the mission. Since there is no way to save game when playing this DLC mission (only applies to this bonus mission), you should set aside some time to play it through...it's not that long if you don't end up getting whacked too much. Overall, I thought this game was well worth the money (I got it on sale, and bundled as the Gold pack) and I am definitely going to play it again!

Posted: December 5, 2011
												Sniper: Ghost Warrior gets a bad rap from most reviewers. Personally I steer clear from most of the generic realistic big name FPS titles so I am rating this based on it's own merits as a sniper. While probably devised using some random Tom Clancy name generator, it is actually a fun game. It does have it's flaws, occasional bugs (Nothing gamebreaking) and over sensitive AI but in essence it is a realistic, highly satisfying sniper/stealth simulator. Each perfectly aimed headshot is rewarding with a slow motion camera following the bullet until the evil generic mexican soldier falls to the ground with his hat flying off. The graphics give the illusion of a crysis competitor through fancy shaders and choppy shadows but are impressive for a much lower budget title. A fun campaign mode, as you can guess multiplayer is just a giant campfest waiting for someone to move. Don't pay more than $10 or $15 for it though if you value your money.

Posted: April 25, 2012
												The moment I started the game, my jaw dropped in awe. If there is one thing Sniper: Ghost Warrior should be remembered for, it'd be its lush, beautiful, tropical setting. Graphically, this game has it down pat. Sadly, the same cannot be said for anything else.The campaign takes you into the lives of a deadly marksman and a trained soldier who are hot on the trail of an elusive weapons dealer. The switches between two characters are the game's poor attempts to add variety.Ghost Warrior is already a subpar game with sporadic A.I. behavior and some nonsensical design choices. Unfortunately, it gets worse during the infantry missions. The gunplay is atrocious and regenerating health saps the excitement of combat.The game's saving grace is twofold. There are few games quite like Sniper. Despite its flaws, there's still fun to be had. And of course: its stealth missions. Nothing is more rewarding than sneaking past an entire platoon of soldiers or picking them off from afar.Grade: C-
